Fig. 6 The changes in concentrations of thymol blue in UV–vis absorption spectra at 597nm in the presence of visible light irradiation and different composition of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4; (A) for x =0.1, (B) for x =0.2, (C) NiMoO4, (D) for x =0.3 and (E) for x =0.4, (F) Cu x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1), (G) Co x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1), (H) CrPO4, (I) catalysts+solution+dark condition and (J) only TB solution+UV light, photocatalyst calcined at amorphous temperatures. Fig. 7 XPS of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1). Table 5 The surface atom concentration for oxygen, Ni, Cr, Mo and P atoms of the Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) alloys by XPS Sample Atomic surface concentration (%) Surface atomic ratio (%) O Ni Mo Cr P Ni/Cr Ni/P Mo/Cr Mo/P Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) 72.46 1.05 1.02 12.24 13.13 8.57 8.00 8.33 7.76 Studies on phase formation temperature and photocatalytic properties of nano-sized solid solution of nickel molybdate and chromium–phosphate (Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4) Tanmay K. Ghorai a b c Debasis Dhak b Sudipta Dalai a Panchanan Pramanik b ⁎ a Department of Chemistry and Chemical Technology, Vidyasagar University, Midnapore 721102, India b Department of Chemistry, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur 721302, India c Department of Chemistry, Bajkul Milani Mahavidyalaya, Kismat Bajkul, Purba Medinipur 721655, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 3220 283322; fax: +91 3222 255303. Graphical abstract The nano-sized Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 was synthesized by CSD method and photocatalytic activity was investigated. The average particle size of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) was found to be 55±10nm and it has effective surface area is ∼72.85m2/g. It is showed the highest photocatalytic activity compared other mixed oxides due to small particle size and high surface area. The photocatalytic activity of various proportions of nickel–chromium–molybdenum–phosphorous (Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4) oxides in the oxidation of thymol blue at pH 8.001 under both UV and visible light has been examined. The nano-size different compositions of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (where x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) photocatalyst were prepared by chemical solution decomposition (CSD) method and characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–vis spectroscopy, Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM), specific surface area (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET)), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and ICP analysis. The variations of phase separation temperature with respect to the amount of different constituents have been studied. The average particle size of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) was found to be 55±10nm measured from Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM) and specific surface area (BET) is found to be ∼72.85m2/g. Keywords Solid solution Nickel molybdate Phosphate Nano-size Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Nickel molybdate (NiMoO4) is an interesting compound because of its structural, electronic and catalytic properties [1–5]. Transition metal molybdates (AMoO4) (A=Ni, Co, Fe, Cu) are promising catalysts for the oxidative dehydrogenation, particularly in the case of propane to propene [6–9], several types of photochemical reactions mainly degradation of different dyes [10]. Among all the transition metal molybdates, nickel molybdates are reported to be the well-known active catalyst for oxidation reaction [11], industrial catalysts for partial oxidation of hydrocarbons and precursors in the synthesis of hydrodesulphurization (HDS) catalysts [12–13]. The catalytic property of NiMoO4 is closely related to its structure [14]. Metal phosphates have got some excellent catalytic applications, in different acid–base catalysis, redox catalysis and photocatalytic processes [15,16]. Chromium phosphate with high surface acidity exhibits various catalytic activity for different areas like acid catalyzed reactions of cyclohexene [17,18], cumene conversion and 2-propanol dehydration [19], oxidative dehydrogenation [20], an excellent ion-exchanger [21–23], electroplates [24] and sorption of divalent metal ions on CrPO4 [25]. Different metal dopant mixed oxides play an important role in many areas of modern technology and are used as catalysts in a large variety of commercial processes such as cracking, hydrogenation, dehydrogenation, oxidative dehydrogenation and regeneration in various chemical and petrochemical industries [26–29]. Some mixed transition metal molybdates and chromites also have good catalytic properties [30,31]. Moreover the catalytic properties of these ceramic oxides, other properties like mechanochemical [32], electron paramagnetic resonance and optical absorption [33], lithium battery cathode material [34], electrical conductivity [35], photovoltaic electrochemical [36] magnetic [37–39], and photochemical properties are now widely used for various applications [40]. The molybdates of cobalt(II), copper(II) and manganese(II) are used in photo electrochemical solar cell as semiconductor electrode [41]. Various properties and applications of these ceramics have been investigated [42,43]. The M x Cr1−x MoO4 (M=transition elements) have remarkable electrical and magnetic properties [44,45] and are used mainly in catalytic applications [46]. The alloy of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 solid solution showed well photocatalytic activity compared to the other M x 1Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (M1 =Cu, Co) solid solution [47] against thymol blue solution in presence of both UV/visible light. Among all the M x 1Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (M1 =Ni, Cu, Co), only Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 is reasonably photoactive (shown in Figs. 5 and 6) compared to the other solid solutions of Cu and Co alloys, against thymol blue solution, for which we have concentrated our discussion mainly on Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 photocatalyst. In this substantiation authors have developed the chemical solution decomposition method to prepare the nano-sized nickel molybdate, and chromium phosphate (Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4) ceramic oxides. Attempts to prepare the solid solution of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 in nano-size have been carried out, because the nano-size may stabilize the thermodynamically unstable solid solution. CrPO4 is used here to act as a diluent of molybdate salt. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals required Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (AR grade, India), (NH4)2MoO4 (AR grade, India), (NH4)2Cr2O7 (AR grade, India), (NH4)H2PO4 (AR grade, India), C2H5OH (99%), HNO3 (65%), NH4OH (25%) triethanolammine (TEA), and Thymol blue (TB) were A.R. reagents produced from B.D.H. of India. 2.2 Synthesis The total synthesis of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 has been performed by two steps. In the first step, the starting materials of nickel molybdates and chromium phosphate were prepared. Nickel molybdates were synthesized by co-precipitation method. The nickel nitrate and ammonium molybdates solutions in a mole ratio of 1:1 were taken in a beaker. Then the aqueous ammonia was added dropwise via vigorous stirring to the above solution to adjust pH to about 9 and a faint green amorphous precipitate was formed. The synthesis procedure is presented in Fig. 1 . The Chromium phosphate was prepared by the process described earlier [47]. In the second step the stoichiometric amounts of NiMoO4 (dissolved in dilute nitric acid) and chromic phosphate (CrPO4) in nitric acid solution were taken in a beaker as per chemical composition of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (where x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) is presented in Fig. 1. The requisite amount of triethanolamine (TEA) was added to this homogeneous solution in such a way that the total metal ions (NiII, CrIII and MoVI) and TEA mole ratio is maintained at 1:4 to maintain the pH at 4–5 to avoid the precipitation of hydroxides of the metal ions. The resulting clear solution of TEA complexed metal ions was then evaporated on hot-plate at about 200°C with constant stirring. After the completion of dehydration, the solution becomes more viscous but without the visible formation of any precipitate or turbidity. Finally it is decomposed to a voluminous, organic black fluffy powder, which is followed by calcination in air at different heat treatment temperatures (shown in Table 1 ) for 2h at a heating rate of 8–10°C/min to get a series of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) alloy powders. These powders were characterized by X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), TG-DTA, EDS X-ray study, specific surface area (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET)), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and ICP analysis. For analysis of composition of samples by EDS X-ray method, we have calibrated the machine with the known compositions. This is required because in presence of Cr3+, Mo6+ always show the lower value of concentration due to excitation-energy transfer from Mo6+ to Cr3+. These compositions are further verified with the analysis of Ni, Cr and Mo by atomic absorbance spectroscopy. 2.3 Photocatalytic test The photocatalytic activity of the above mixed oxide solid solutions Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) are substantiated in the following path. The photocatalytic reaction was carried out by 400W Ultrahigh-pressure Hg lamp (PHILIPS-HPL-N, G/74/2, MBF-400) with a maximum emission at about 364nm was used as the light source. In all experiments, the reaction temperature was kept at 28±2°C by using an air conditioner. Reaction solutions were prepared by adding each photocatalyst nano powder (0.1g) into each of a 50ml of thymol blue solution. The photocatalytic reactions were carried out in a simple cubic system, where UV light (λ >280nm) was irradiated on the sample vessel with frequent stirring of the mixture, keeping at the bottom of the UV light. Besides that, the photocatalytic performance was also observed in presence of visible light (sun light) (λ >400nm). In both cases, a small volume (1ml) of reactant liquid was siphoned out at regular interval of time for analysis. It was then centrifuged at 1500rpm for 15min, filtered through a 0.2μm-millipore filter to remove the suspended catalyst particles and concentration of dye was measured by absorption spectrometry using UV–vis spectrometer (UV-1601, SHIMADZU) at its wavelength of maximum absorption. After leaching the Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 powders through filtration with Whatman −42, the reaction solution (after reaction) was subjected to inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis in order to measure the amount of leached Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 alloy. 2.4 Characterization Simultaneous thermogravimetry and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA, Shimadzu DT-40 Co., Kyoto, Japan) with a heating rate of 2°C/min in a static air atmosphere was used to study the thermal decomposition behavior of the as-prepared (dried) photocatalysts with α-Al2O3 as the reference. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to identify phases present in the samples. A Rigaku RINT-2100 rotating anode XRD system generating monochromated Cu Kα radiation with continuous scanning mode at rate of 2°min−1 and operating conditions of 40kV and 40mA was used to obtain XRD patterns. The stoichiometry of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 alloys has been examined by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (GEOL JMS-5800). A nitrogen adsorption system (BECKMAN COULTER SA3100) was employed to measure Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) adsorption–desorption isotherms at liquid nitrogen temperature of 77K. The sample morphology was observed by a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Model Philips TM-30, Philips Research Laboratories) operated at accelerating voltage of 200kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out in an Axis-Ultra X-ray photoelectron spectrophotometer in vacuum (1×10−5 Pa). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermal study of the precursors Thermogravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) (Model DT-40, Shimadzu Co., Kyoto, Japan) has been performed in air at a heating rate of 2°C/min. The DTA curve in Fig. 2 indicates that the Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.4) precursor powder decomposes exothermally, with a sharp peak at 353.3°C. Another exothermic peak appears at around 900°C, which may be due to the phase separation of the two mixed oxides. This phase separation is later confirmed during XRD analysis (Fig. 3 ). This major exothermic peak at 353.3°C can be assigned to major decomposition of metal (TEA) complexes. From the graph it is also observed that the metal-TEA precursor powder exhibits weight loss up to 550°C and above 550°C the weight becomes almost constant. This indicates that below 550°C, a metal complex along with unreacted amine decomposes. The whole thermal process is associated with the evolution of a large amount of gases (such as oxides of carbon and nitrogen and water vapor) that is reflected by the total weight loss of 70% in the TGA curve. 3.2 XRD analysis The X-ray diffractograph in Fig. 3 show that those are amorphous below a certain temperature of heat treatment. The phase separation temperature decreases with increasing the mole percent of NiMoO4. Table 1 show the temperatures above which phase separations occur. The XRD peaks of the newly formed compounds reveal that most of the major peaks are the XRD pattern of nickel molybdates. The solubility NiMoO4 in CrPO4 is poor. They are not miscible in any reasonable molar ratio. However in nano-structured form they can form solid solution, which has been manifested in these studies. The nano-structured compounds have been examined to find the atomic level dispersion through EDS X-ray study in Table 2 . The sizes of crystallites separated from various compositions at their phase separation temperatures have been evaluated from Scherrer equation. The data of crystallite sizes obtained from the diffractographs have been presented in Table 3 . It is noted that the lowest crystallite sizes of the NiMoO4 is around 21nm. It is probably due to higher reactivity for growth of crystallites below of 21nm. 3.3 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) study The finer details of the particles and their morphologies have been investigated by TEM (Model Philips TM-30, Philips Research Laboratories). The bright-field (BF) electron micrograph of the Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) powder produced at 950°C (2h) reflects narrow distribution of particles, with an average particle diameter of 55±10nm which is shown in Fig. 4 . 3.4 Specific surface area analysis During the evaporation of precursor solution triethanolamine and its complexes generate mesoporous phase in the intermittent temperature. The BET surface area measurements by nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm in BECKMAN COULTER SA3100 shows that powder produced at their calcination temperatures for Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4, has effective surface area around 65–73m2/g; the corresponding surface area is 72.851, 69.323, 67.421 and 65.736m2/g for various ‘x’ is 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 at 850°C (shown in Table 3), respectively. The attempts made to make such solid solution by co-precipitation were unsuccessful. Tap densities of final powders have been measured and presented in Table 3. 3.5 Photocatalytic activity of the prepared samples In order to obtain some information on the potential application in photocatalysis of our solution UV–vis spectra were obtained. The changes in concentrations of thymol blue solution in UV–vis absorption spectra at 597nm as a function of both UV–vis light irradiation time in the prepared photocatalysts are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 . In both cases using Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) photocatalyst, the decolorization process is more faster compared to the other solid solutions for photodegradation of thymol blue solution under similar conditions. Time taken for complete degradation of thymol blue is 4h and 5h in presence of visible light and UV light, respectively. So it indicates that the photodegradation is much faster in presence of visible light rather than UV light. In presence of catalyst, both cases the degradation rate of TB is much high ∼100 times for visible light and ∼55 times for UV light (rate measured at end point for both cases) respectively compared to the absence of catalyst. The M x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (M=Co, Cu) solid solution does not show any photocatalytic activity for both cases. The rate constants of degrading thymol blue using Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4), NiMoO4, Cu x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1), Co x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1), CrPO4, catalysts+solution+dark condition and only TB solution+UV light, as photocatalysts are listed in Table 4 . With increase of the different dopant percentage of NiMoO4 with CrPO4 solid solution, the rate of photodegradation decreases and becomes ineffective for CrPO4 solid solution. 3.6 XPS analysis XPS spectrum of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) alloy is shown in Fig. 7 . The XPS of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 is remaining almost unchanged before and after photochemical reaction was also observed. So, recycled and reused catalyst in the photochemical reaction and its photocatalytic activity remain same as before. The result reveals that the XPS spectra of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 alloy corresponding to NiO, Cr2O3, MoO3 and P2O5 specimens on the surface. It indicates that the metal ions exist as Ni(II), Cr(VI), Mo(VI) and P(V) oxidation states. The photoelectron peaks are around at 854.1, 587.8, 233.0, 192.7/135.5 and 533.4eV, which correspond to the binding energy of Ni 2p, Cr 2p, Mo 2p, P 2s/P 2p and O 1s of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 alloy. The ICP analysis of the reaction solution after reaction is performed which does not give any significant amount element present (∼5–10ppm) in the reaction solution after filtration with Whatman −42. The surface atomic concentration of the Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) alloy estimated from XPS was shown in Table 5 . The surface atom concentrations for oxygen, nickel, chromium and phosphorous atoms and the atomic ratio for Ni/Cr (8.57), Ni/P (8.00), Mo/Cr (8.33) and Mo/P (7.76) were obtained from the results of XPS analysis. 3.7 Mechanism Initially Ni and Mo exist as a Ni(II) and Mo(VI) oxidation state, Ni(II) is one of reactive species on the catalyst surface and Mo(VI) ion helps to compensate the charge of the lattice. When the thymol blue dye is irradiated with UV light, the dye is discolored within the time of reaction through the mutual contact between the dye and catalyst. This is probably due to efficient generation of electron and hole through transformation of Ni(II) to Ni(III) ion, where electron resides in conduction band and hole is captured forming Ni3+, which efficiently reacts with intermediates of dye molecules and decolorized the dyes. 4 Conclusion The present study has shown that the meta-stable solid solutions of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 photocatalyst synthesized by CSD method. These mixed oxides are photoactive due to high surface area ∼72.85m2/g and largely dependent on their microstructure. The average particle size of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) was found to be 55±10nm measured from TEM. In the nanoparticle phase, the surface to volume ratio increases drastically and the surface atoms include an increasing fraction of the total particulate volume having high defect structures. Thus they are expected to show drastically improved catalytic properties. coredata.dc:description: The photocatalytic activity of various proportions of nickel–chromium–molybdenum–phosphorous (Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4) oxides in the oxidation of thymol blue at pH 8.001 under both UV and visible light has been examined. The nano-size different compositions of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (where x =0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) photocatalyst were prepared by chemical solution decomposition (CSD) method and characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–vis spectroscopy, Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM), specific surface area (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET)), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and ICP analysis. The variations of phase separation temperature with respect to the amount of different constituents have been studied. The average particle size of Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4 (x =0.1) was found to be 55±10nm measured from Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM) and specific surface area (BET) is found to be ∼72.85m2/g.
coredata.dc:title: Studies on phase formation temperature and photocatalytic properties of nano-sized solid solution of nickel molybdate and chromium–phosphate (Ni x Cr1−x Mo x P1−x O4)
